bioprojects.title: Strain of the causative agent of plague isolated from a soil sample from Nepal

description.title: Generic sample from Yersinia pestis Nepal516

assembly_info.comments:
Yersinia pestis Nepa1516A, isolated from a soil sample from Nepal, is being sequenced for a comparative genome analysis of Yersinia pestis strains from different parts of the world. It is a separate isolate from the previously sequenced Y. pestis Nepal516.
Two libraries were constructed with average insert sizes of 1879 bp (39925 reads) and 9479 bp (39324 reads). Additional sequences from primer walk reads and PCR reactions were used to close gaps and improve quality. The assembled sequences were aligned with the finished genomic sequence of Y. pestis Nepal516 to predict order and orientation of contigs and scaffolds. This order and orientation is based on the assumption that no major rearrangements have occurred between the two genomes; however this has not been experimentally verified.
Genome sequencing, assembly, and finishing were performed by the Department of Energy's Joint Genome Institute (DOE-JGI), in Walnut Creek, CA and at Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM. Annotation and database submission were carried out by the Enteropathogen Resource Integration Center, Madison, WI (ERIC http://www.ericbrc.org/portal/eric), a Bioinformatics Resource Center supported by the NIH/NIAID.
Funding for sequencing was provided by the Intelligence Technology Innovation Center; funding for the annotation was provided by the NIH/NIAID.

bioprojects.title: Causes plague

description.title: Generic sample from Yersinia pestis CA88-4125

assembly_info.comments:
Yersinia pestis CA88-4125 was originally isolated in Monterey County, California. This area is very close to San Francisco, where Yersinia pestis is first thought to have become established in native populations of rodents. Subsequent spread of plague to the rest of the western United States probably originated from this region. As such, comparisons of this strain to other North American Y. pestis strains should provide interesting insights into how Y. pestis mutated as it spread across the western United States. Three libraries were constructed with average insert sizes of 2874 bp, 3961 bp, and 4758 bp from which 37463, 21554, and 24262 reads were sequenced, respectively. This amount of sequence represents 10X coverage of the genome. After two rounds of autofinish sequencing, several scaffolds were connected by PCR end sequences and shatter libraries, and a number of duplications were resolved with transposon bombed subclones.
Draft sequencing was performed at the Joint Genome Institute (JGI) production genomics facility in Walnut Creek, CA. Two rounds of genome finishing was performed by the JGI at Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM. Annotation and database submission were carried out by the Enteropathogen Resource Integration Center, Madison, WI (ERIC http://www.ericbrc.org/portal/eric), a Bioinformatics Resource Center supported by the NIH/NIAID.
The NIAID funded Bioinformatics Resource Center PathoSystems Resource Integration Center (PATRIC; http://patricbrc.vbi.vt.edu/) is responsible for annotation updates of this record.
Plasmids pCD1 and pMT1 are GenBank Accession Numbers CP000722-CP000723.

bioprojects.title: Biovar Orientalis strain for comparative analysis

description.title: Generic sample from Yersinia pestis biovar Orientalis str. PEXU2

organism.organism_name: Yersinia pestis biovar Orientalis str. PEXU2

assembly_info.comments:
Yersinia pestis biovar Orientalis str. PEXU2 was isolated from a rodent in Brazil in 1966, and is being sequenced for a comparative genome analysis of Y. pestis strains from different parts of the world. This strain lacks the Low-Calcium-Response (LCR) plasmid pCD, found in most Y. pestis isolates.
Two libraries were constructed with average insert sizes of 4161 bp (33045 reads) and 6536 bp (32229 reads). Additional sequences from primer walk reads and PCR reactions were used to close gaps and improve quality. The assembled sequences were aligned with the finished genomic sequence of Y. pestis CO92 to predict order and orientation of contigs and scaffolds. This order and orientation is based on the assumption no major rearrangements other than the ones noted have occurred between the two genomes; however this has not been experimentally verified. Chromosome_contig1 contains an inversion between approximate coordinates 1456000 and 1589000; plasmid pMT has an inversion from approximately 57000 to the end of the contig.
Genome sequencing, assembly, and finishing were performed by the Department of Energy's Joint Genome Institute (DOE-JGI), in Walnut Creek, CA and at Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM. Annotation and database submission were carried out by the Enteropathogen Resource Integration Center, Madison, WI (ERIC http://www.ericbrc.org/portal/eric), a Bioinformatics Resource Center supported by the NIH/NIAID.
Funding for sequencing was provided by the Intelligence Technology Innovation Center; funding for the annotation was provided by the NIH/NIAID.
For further information about the source of the DNA, contact Tom Brettin (brettin@lanl.gov) or David Bruce (dbruce@lanl.gov).

description.title: Generic sample from Yersinia pestis biovar Orientalis str. India 195

organism.organism_name: Yersinia pestis biovar Orientalis str. India 195

assembly_info.comments:
Yersinia pestis biovar Orientalis str. India 195 is a human isolate from India and is being sequenced for a comparative genome analysis of Yersinia pestis strains from different parts of the world.
Two libraries were constructed with average insert sizes of 1820 bp (31762 reads) and 7644 bp (24753 reads). Additional sequences from primer walk reads and PCR reactions were used to close gaps and improve quality. The assembled sequences were aligned with the finished genomic sequence of Y. pestis CO92 to predict order and orientation of contigs and scaffolds. This order and orientation is based on the assumption no major rearrangements other than the ones noted have occurred between the two genomes; however this has not been experimentally verified. Several rearrangements have been observed in India 195 relative to CO92: 1) an inversion in Chromosome_contig23, between approximate coordinates 316000 and 451500; 2) an inversion in Chromosome_contig19, between approximate coordinates 192000 and 289000; 3) a deletion of about 100 Kb has occurred in Chromosome_contig13 at approximately 158000; 4) a rearrangement in Chromosome_contig02 through Chromosome_contig07.
Genome sequencing, assembly, and finishing were performed by the Department of Energy's Joint Genome Institute (DOE-JGI), in Walnut Creek, CA and at Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM. Annotation and database submission were carried out by the Enteropathogen Resource Integration Center, Madison, WI (ERIC http://www.ericbrc.org/portal/eric), a Bioinformatics Resource Center supported by the NIH/NIAID.

bioprojects.title: An atypical enzootic variant

description.title: Generic sample from Yersinia pestis Pestoides A

assembly_info.comments:
Yersinia pestis Pestoides A is an atypical enzootic or nonepidemic 'pestoides' variant of Yersinia pestis, probably acquired by the US from the USSR in the 1960s or 1970s. The strain is closely related to Pestoides B-D; these strains are subspecies altaica, versus the previously sequenced Pestoides F strain which is subspecies caucasica. These atypical Y. pestis variants are considered important for understanding the evolution of acute virulence because they share characteristics of close relative Yersinia enterocolitica, a nonlethal enteric pathogen.
Sanger sequencing data was collected from a library with an average insert size of 5931 bp (30529 reads). An additional 2500 454 pyrosequencing reads were collected, along with approximately 4170 primer walk finishing reads. Misassemblies may have occurred in the sequence where 454 data is not verified by Sanger paired end reads or PCR.
Genome sequencing, assembly, and finishing were performed by the Department of Energy's Joint Genome Institute (DOE-JGI), in Walnut Creek, CA and at Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM. Annotation and database submission were carried out by the Enteropathogen Resource Integration Center, Madison, WI (ERIC http://www.ericbrc.org/portal/eric), a Bioinformatics Resource Center supported by the NIH/NIAID.
Funding for sequencing was provided by the Intelligence Technology Innovation Center; funding for the annotation was provided by the NIH/NIAID.
For further information about the source of the DNA, contact Mikeljon Nikolich (Mikeljon.Nikolich@amedd.army.mil) or Luther Lindler (Luther.Lindler@dhs.gov).
The NIAID funded Bioinformatics Resource Center PathoSystems Resource Integration Center (PATRIC; http://patricbrc.vbi.vt.edu/) is responsible for annotation updates of this record.
Genome Coverage: 30x (5x Sanger; 25x 454)
Sequencing Technology: ABI;454

organism.organism_name: Yersinia pestis biovar Orientalis str. IP275

bioprojects.title: Orientalis subtype isolated in Madagascar that causes plague

description.title: Generic sample from Yersinia pestis biovar Orientalis str. IP275

organism.organism_name: Yersinia pestis biovar Orientalis str. IP275

assembly_info.comments: Yersinia pestis strain IP275 (original name: 17/95) was isolated in Madagascar in 1995 from a human case of bubonic plague. The patient, a 16-year-old boy from the Ambalavao district of Madagascar presented with fever, chills, and myalgia suggestive of malaria and was treated with quinine. Three days later, the appearance of a right inguinal bubo with high-grade fever (temperature of 41C), delirium, and prostration led to the diagnosis of plague. The bubo was punctured, and the patient was treated with twice-daily intramuscular injections of streptomycin (2 g per day for 4 days) and oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (2g per day for 10 days). The patient recovered but had severe asthenia for more than a month. This strain is of biovar Orientalis.
